“On the foregoing basis, I request WorkSafe determine the AFL an unsafe workplace until such time as safe Return to Play Protocols and the multi-modality testing regimes and concussion passport are introduced.”
While Jess continues to deal with WorkSafe, potential legal action could cease if the AFL introduces a multimillion-dollar insurance fund, which former players impacted by head knocks could tap into.

In his letter to Josevski, Jess “alleges that at all relevant times the AFL, in breach of Section 23 of the Act, failed to ensure, as far as reasonably possible, that players in the AFL, AFLW and second-tier competitions were not exposed to risks to their health and safety arising from the unsafe Return to Play Protocols in conduct of the competitions.

Player agent and concussion campaigner Peter Jess is intensifying his bid for Worksafe Victoria to prosecute the AFL for alleged negligence in dealing with concussion.

In what shapes as a key plank of Jess’ fight to launch individual legal action on behalf of players impacted by neurological issues, Jess has met with Nikola Josevski, a senior WorkSafe investigator, and provided a fresh letter of complaint.

The AFL, however, has tightened its protocols considerably over the past decade, including introducing a minimum 12-day break for concussed players, and last year allowing teams on game day to replace an injured or concussed player.

Sources say Josevski opened his investigation in September last year – there had been an earlier WorkSafe report on the AFL in 2020 – with Jess hoping the latest report ultimately lands with the Director of Public Prosecutions.
